author: sky.cactus
content: Has anyone thought about merklized execution?

author: sky.cactus
content: Purely brainstorming, maybe a silly idea, but the idea would be that one could prove any step of execution with a merkle proof and the entire execution would be represented by a single merkle root.

author: lightclient
content: i think this is sort of what arbitrum does

author: sky.cactus
content: Heh, I was just typing out that this sort of thing would be useful for Arbitrum.

author: sky.cactus
content: I guess I can ask them how they are doing it, I didn't think it was merkle proofs but maybe it is.

author: .vbuterin
content: We *kinda* had a version of this before where there were intermediate state roots saved after every tx

author: .vbuterin
content: We got rid of that because (i) it increased total state execution times by ~20% because of the extra hashing and (ii) it doesn't actually help much because in the worst case there would be one transaction as big as the block

author: .vbuterin
content: But I suppose if there was a version that properly does it at every point of execution that would be interesting

author: .vbuterin
content: Would need to watch the overhead though

author: .vbuterin
content: And we'd also need to make a standard serialization for memory and stack and callstack
